Last night, in the downstairs of a pub on the fringes of the city, two groups of people met. One group builds tools, the other uses them. They came to learn from one another, to swap and ideas and secrets, and to help define the way we see the world‚Ä¶

They came from many different organisations, some of them notionally¬†competitive. Some were old hands at this, meeting regularly over the course of the last year. Others were taking their first steps into a new world. One key organiser works for an organisation that has come under considerable public scrutiny in recent months for its illicit activities. Another, a speaker, in fact, was from the very organisation that has done so much to expose those activities. With a crowd like this, the talk was bound to be of paranoia, of safety and privacy, and of wresting control from the moribund hands of those who fail to understand the reality of today.

[![Hacks and Hackers London](https://i2.wp.com/www.onemanandhisblog.com/content/images/2011/08/IMG_1656-thumb-520x189-2012.jpg?resize=520%2C189)](https://i1.wp.com/www.onemanandhisblog.com/content/images/2011/08/IMG_1656.jpg)

Who were these shadowy denizens of London? What brought them together?

They are hacks. And they are hackers. And this was [Hacks/Hackers London](http://meetuplondon.hackshackers.com/events/17314533/).


## Hacks and Coders in a bar

So, yes, it was just a bunch of journos and coders sat together in the downstairs bar of a pub, drinking painfully expensive beer and talking about security and the perpetual digital revolution we‚Äôre in right now. But you know what? They all had something in common: a desire to learn, and an excitement about the future. (And¬†slightly¬†lighter wallets by the end of the evening)

The hackers are the real techies. They are the people who play with code and consider it fun. The journalists? They‚Äôre just users of tools, not builders of them, looking for new ways of plying their trades with those new tools the hackers are creating. Most people in that room who are working journalists can‚Äôt code their way out of a wet paper bag ‚Äì myself included. But they are the sort of people who want journalism to keep moving forward, to keep pace with the digital revolution and find new ways of expressing itself.

In fact, this gathering was the the antithesis of the kerfuffle about [what editors think about web skills](http://www.onemanandhisblog.com/archives/2011/08/nostalgia_is_not_a_viable_approach_to_jo.html) that we‚Äôve seen over the last couple of days. Too much of the¬†commentary¬†around that [much-discussed report](http://www.nctj.com/qualifications/national-certificate/nce-report) reflected the attitudes of people who are unwilling to move out of their comfort zone, who like things very much they way they are thankyouverymuch, and who are quite willing to denigrate anyone with a more open mind as ‚Äútechies‚Äù or, as the editor of *Press Gazette* quite memorably tweeted ‚Äú[new media blowhards](https://twitter.com/#!/Domponsford/status/106033866636132352)‚Äú.

Thanks, Dominic. Nice to know that our trade title is so respectful of its whole¬†constituency. This was a gathering of people who care enough about their profession to give up their evening to learn new things, and to share with others. I know which group I‚Äôd rather be part of.¬†


## Pragmatic optimism

And it wasn‚Äôt an exercise in starry-eyed optimism, either. This was not a gathering of true believers, come to hear a¬†familiar¬†sermon and sign¬†familiar¬†hymns. No, the [first presentation](http://dropsafe.crypticide.com/article/5078) was exploring the idea that protecting the identities of sources gets ever harder in the digital age. Stick your head in the sand about digital skills, and you run the risk of failing to protect your sources.¬†

[![Live tweeting Hacks and Hackers London](https://i2.wp.com/www.onemanandhisblog.com/content/images/2011/08/IMG_1658-thumb-200x149-2014.jpg?resize=200%2C149)](https://i0.wp.com/www.onemanandhisblog.com/content/images/2011/08/IMG_1658.jpg)

- [Sex, Lies and Digital News](http://sarahbookerpress.wordpress.com/2011/08/25/hhldn-sex-lies-and-digital-news/)

(I‚Äôm spotting a theme in the naming‚Ä¶ How can I resist following their lead?) There‚Äôs much to learn in there, and it won‚Äôt even cost you a ¬£4 pint. üòâ

And there are plenty of future meetings planned. So, [come along](http://meetuplondon.hackshackers.com/events/17314546/), drink over-priced beer and help us find new ways of making the news matter.
